For the AI algorithm, the balance between the positive and negative predictions can be adjusted. This adjustment results in a trade-off between the four outcomes in the confusion matrix: more of one column requires less of the other column, while the total numbers of TP+FN and TN+FP (the row sums) stay the same.

This adjustment can be made by varying the decision threshold θ (theta). One can set the decision threshold θ between [0;1]:

  • The larger the threshold θ, the more negative predictions are made, i.e., more TN and FN.
  • The smaller the threshold θ, the more positive predictions are made, i.e., more TP and FP.

For the confusion matrix we introduced earlier, we show the relationship of the threshold θ and the absolute prediction outcomes in the following table.

Confusion Matrix
Predicted Class
Positive Negative Row sum
Actual Class Positive TP FN constant
Negative FP TN constant
Column sum Increases with
decreasing θ		 Increases with
increasing θ
